column6: Which of the following is NOT a bone of the axial skeleton?
column12:
The deltoid is NOT a bone of the axial skeleton; it is a muscle of the shoulder. The ethmoid, sphenoid, and hyoid are all part of the axial skeleton. 
The axial skeleton is the central part of the human skeleton, consisting of 80 bones that include the skull, vertebral column, rib cage, and hyoid bone. It serves to protect vital organs such as the brain, heart, and lungs, and provides support for the body.

column6: Which of the following is a function of the skeletal system?
In which of the following bone structures do osteocytes live?
column12: Osteocytes are mature bone cells that originate from osteoblasts and are the most common type of cell found in mature bone. They play a crucial role in maintaining bone health by regulating mineral metabolism and communicating with other bone cells to manage bone remodeling.  Osteocytes live in small spaces called lacunae, which are located within the lamellae of an osteon. These cells extend their processes into tiny channels known as canaliculi.

column12: The trochanter is a bony prominence on the femur (thigh bone) that serves as an attachment point for muscles involved in hip movement. Humans have two main trochanters: the greater trochanter, located on the outer side of the femur, and the lesser trochanter, found on the inner side.

column9: warming of inhaled air to body temperature before exhaling

column6: Evaporation of sweat cools our body because the evaporating water molecules
column8: transfer kinetic energy away from us.

column6: Human body core temperature is usually maintained within which of the fol- lowing ranges?
What causes the cooling effect that we experience when sweating?
column8: conduction of heat to the surrounding air then convection
column9: dripping off of warm sweat from our skin

column6: Hyperthermia is a core body temperature greater than which of the following temperatures?
How does the evaporation of sweat work as a heat loss mechanism?
column7: sweat is produced at a lower temperature than skin so cools the body by conduction.
column8: sweat promotes vasodilation which promotes heat loss by infra-red radiation.

column6: What is the temperature (in °C) below which the body is said to be hypothermic?
Which heat loss avenues are reduced by wearing clothes?
column8: conduction and convection. 20 Energy and Heat 505

column6: What may be said about the amount of energy in the form of infra-red electro- magnetic waves that is radiated from our bodies?
column7: It depends on our body’s temperature.
column8: It would be greater if our layer of subcutaneous fat was thicker.
column9: It may be increased by contact between the body and an object with tem- perature lower than the body’s temperature

column6: Except for one situation described below, water molecules changing state from liquid to gas are involved in the cooling effect. Which one?
column7: a cold wind blowing against your skin

column6: What is the healthy human core body temperature?
How does subcutaneous adipose tissue assist the body to regulate its temperature?
column7: It conducts heat more readily than lean tissue so promotes heat loss.
column8: It stores heat energy so acts like a “heat sink”.
column9: It produces sweat for secretion via sweat glands.
column10: It conducts heat less readily than lean tissue so insulates the body.

column6: When is radiation an effective form of heat loss from the body?
column7: When we expose a greater amount of bare skin.
column8: When our body temperature is greater than that of our surroundings.
column9: When blood vessels close to the body surface are vasoconstricted.
column10: When our body temperature is less than that of our surroundings.

column6: Which choice explains how the evaporation of sweat “cools” our body?
column7: Evaporating water molecules carry with them more than the average amount of kinetic energy which leaves the remaining molecules with a lower aver-age kinetic energy.
column8: The body loses more heat through the infrared radiation emitted by sweat than it gains from the infrared radiation emitted by the surroundings.
column9: Sweat is at a lower temperature than our core body temperature so sweat on our skin cools us by conduction.
column10: The water molecules in sweat are at a higher temperature than our core body temperature so losing sweat leaves us cooler due to the mass of water lost.

column6: Why does an ice pack applied to a bruise reduce swelling?
column7: Less ﬂ uid leaks from the bruise due to the diminished nerve impulses.
column9: It reduces the metabolic rate at the local site.
column10: It increases the viscosity of blood below the ice pack.

column6: The skin is usually at a lower temperature than the body’s core temperature (37 °C). What is the reason for this?
column7: The layer of adipose tissue in the hypodermis insulates the skin from the core temperature.
column8: The sweating mechanism is able to lower the skin’s temperature.
column9: Vasoconstriction restricts the amount of blood that is brought close to the skin surface.
column10: Heat loss through conduction, convection and radiation keeps the skin at a lower temperature.

column6: A person lightly dressed in shorts, shoes and a shirt is sitting on a cushioned chair in their shady backyard where the air temperature is 12 °C. There is no wind yet they feel uncomfortably cool. What is their major avenue of heat loss?

column7: The skin is at a lower temperature than the bell.
column8: The stethoscope bell is a good conductor of heat.
column9: The stethoscope bell is a poor conductor of heat.
column10: Sweat evaporating from under the bell cools the skin.

column6: Why does perspiring cause heat energy to be lost from the body? Because:

column10: sweat on the skin allows heat to be lost to the air by conduction.

column6: Which of the following is the most acceptable deﬁ nition of the term “power”?
column8: that which is stored and can be fully recovered and converted to kinetic energy.
column9: the concept applied to that which gives an object the ability to do work.
column10: the sum of an object’s potential and kinetic energies.

column6: Which of the following correctly states the principle of conservation of energy in terms of the human body? (assume no foodstuffs are consumed and no urine or faeces are excreted).
column7: Q = s × m × ΔT (Q = energy, s = speciﬁ c heat of tissue, m = body mass, T = body temperature)
column8: The energy stored in the human body is equal to the energy lost from the body plus the work done by the body.
column9: The energy value of the food we eat must exceed the energy value of the muscular activity we perform.
column10: The change in the energy stored in the body is equal to the heat lost from the body plus the work done by the body.

column6: Which of the statements is a description of basal metabolic rate in a human?
column7: The sum total of the energy released per minute by all of the chemical reac- tions that occur in the body.
column8: the rate of energy utilisation during “absolute rest”.
column9: The power generated by the body’s activities.
column10: The oxygen consumption (in l/min) of an individual.

column6: Which explanation of the cooling effect produced by an ice-pack when applied to the skin is the best one?
column7: Cold applied to the skin causes vasodilation thus allowing more blood to pass through the tissue adjacent to the ice pack and be cooled.
column8: Heat withdrawn from the body is used to provide the ice with the latent heat of vaporisation it requires to melt, until melting is complete, the tempera- ture of the icepack remains constant. 20 Energy and Heat 509
column9: Cold transfers along its temperature gradient – from ice pack to skin – the melting ice & water mixture ensures good contact with the skin.
column10: Heat withdrawn from the body (at 37 °C) is used to provide the ice (at 0 °C) with the latent heat of fusion it requires to melt, until melting is complete, the temperature of the icepack doesn’t rise appreciably.

column6: Which is the correct distinction between temperature and heat?
column7: Temperature is a measure of the amount of heat in an object and heat is the energy that ﬂ ows between objects which have different temperatures.
column8: Heat is a measure of the energy contained within an object and temperature is the objective measurement of heat.
column9: Temperature is a measure of the average kinetic energy of particles and heat is the energy that ﬂ ows between objects as a result of a temperature difference.
column10: Heat is the energy that ﬂ ows from a cold object to a hotter object and tem- perature measures the average random kinetic energy of the particles.

column6: A cold pack, applied to reduce swelling, is more effective if it contains melting ice at 0 °C rather than water at 0 °C. Why is this?
column7: Because ice cools by conduction whereas water cools by convection.
column8: Because initially the melting ice is colder than the cold water.
column9: Because ice has a higher latent heat of vaporisation than water.
column10: Because melting ice remains at 0 °C until it has all melted.
